thread.title: Urban Meyer joining list of best coaches Rutgers hosted
thread.title_full: Urban Meyer joining list of best coaches Rutgers hosted

title: Urban Meyer joining list of best coaches Rutgers hosted
text:
Mack Brown, Texas: Six years before he led Texas to the national championship, Brown was on the visitor’s sideline for Rutgers' home opener under the lights in 1999 . 
Texas, which beat Rutgers 48-14 at home in 1997, jumped out to a 21-3 first-quarter lead. 
Brown was fired at the end of the 2013 season. 
Frank Beamer, Virginia Tech: In his first trip to Rutgers, Beamer lost 50-49 on a last-second 15-yard touchdown pass from Bryan Fortay to Chris Brantley as Rutgers celebrated Homecoming 1992 . 
Beamer got plenty of revenge, winning the next five times the old Big East rivals met in Piscataway. 
If the winningest active coach in the FBS is still at the helm of Virginia Tech in 2023, he will be back in town. 
Virginia Tech coach Frank Beamer had reason to smile after winning at Rutgers in 1999. (Photo: AP) 
Steve Spurrier, Duke: In his first season as a “Head Ball Coach” at the college level, the later-renowned offensive guru Spurrier couldn’t solve Rutgers' defense in a 7-0 loss at Giants Stadium. 
Rutgers halfback Harry Henderson broke a scoreless tie with six minutes left in the fourth quarter on a rain-soaked night in front of a sparse crowd. 
Spurrier earned 228 victories at Duke, Florida and South Carolina before abruptly retiring last week . He led Florida to the national title in 1996. Rutgers football's Top 10 games of pre-Big Ten era 
Brian Kelly, Cincinnati: Before becoming coach at Notre Dame, Kelly spent three seasons at Cincinnati and went 3-0 against Rutgers during that span, including road wins in 2007 and 2009. 
Kelly picked up a fourth win against Rutgers when Notre Dame prevailed in the 2013 Pinstripe Bowl, one season after losing to Alabama in the BCS National Championship Game. 
In his first season as a college football head coach, Steve Spurrier, who retired just last week, lost to Rutgers in 1987. (Photo: Jonathan Bachman, AP) 
Johnny Majors, Pittsburgh and Tennessee: In his second stint at Pittsburgh, which he coached to the national title in 1976, Majors beat Rutgers at Giants Stadium in 1993 and lost at Rutgers Stadium in 1995. 
Majors notched a 7-0 win against Rutgers with Tennessee at Giants Stadium in 1983. 
Tom Coughlin, Boston College: Better known for his stints in the NFL, including two Super Bowl titles with the Giants, Coughlin was the losing coach when Rutgers hosted its first-ever Big East game in 1991. He beat Rutgers at Giants Stadium in 1993. 
Rutgers also had visits from two other current NFL head coaches, Bruce Arians of the Arizona Cardinals when he was at Temple in the 1980s and Jim Caldwell of the Detroit Lions when he was at Wake Forest in 1997. 
Before he won two Super Bowls with the Giants, Tom Coughlin coached in the Big East at Boston College from 1991-93. (Photo: The Tennesean) 
Don Nehlen, West Virginia: The College Football Hall of Famer was the 17th-winningest coach in the sport's history (202 victories) when he retired in 2001. 
Rutgers didn’t join the Big East until 1991 but faced West Virginia every season from Nehlen’s first in Morgantown in 1980 through 2011. Nehlen was 4-2 in Piscataway and 4-1 against Rutgers at Giants Stadium. 
Jerry Claiborne, Kentucky: A former player for Bear Bryant, Claiborne won 178 games but lost 19-18 to Rutgers at Giants Stadium in 1987. 
​ Tubby Raymond, Delaware: The 300-game winner went 3-3 against Rutgers from 1967 through 1973 but won just once in four games On the Banks. He remained Delaware’s coach through 2001. 
Staff Writer Ryan Dunleavy: rdunleavy@gannettnj.com 1 CONNECT 10 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read or Share this story: http://on.app.com/1RVMRli TOP VIDEOS
